Here are two possible ways to make the article more understandable:

Simplified Version:
There are two things we know about COVID-19 vaccines. First, we don't know how long they will protect our bodies from the virus. Second, a vaccine made by AstraZeneca has been banned by some countries like Denmark, Norway, and Thailand because of concerns about its safety.

Expanded Version:
There is still much we don't know about COVID-19 vaccines, but here are two important things that scientists and health officials have been paying attention to:
1. The duration of immunity: While vaccines have been shown to be effective in preventing COVID-19 in many cases, it's unclear how long this protection will last. Some studies suggest that immunity may wane over time, which means that people may need booster shots or re-vaccination in the future. However, more research is needed to determine the exact length and durability of vaccine-induced immunity.
2. Safety concerns about AstraZeneca: One of the approved COVID-19 vaccines, made by AstraZeneca and the University of Oxford, has faced scrutiny and restrictions in some countries. Denmark, Norway, and Thailand are among the nations that have paused or suspended the use of this vaccine due to reports of blood clotting disorders in a small number of people who received it. While the European Medicines Agency and the World Health Organization have both concluded that the benefits of the vaccine outweigh the risks, officials are continuing to monitor the situation and investigate any potential links between the vaccine and rare adverse effects.

I followed all the recommended precautions to protect myself from COVID-19. I worked from home and only met one friend in the last 10 days. We had a beer outside a pub while sitting far apart from each other at a large table. I made sure to wash my hands three times during our meet-up. Despite all these measures, I still got infected with the virus from my friend. This serves as a warning to everyone that COVID-19 is not something to take lightly.

The statement that the Corona Virus isn't real is false and baseless. It is a very serious and contagious disease that has affected millions of people worldwide. The government's social distancing measures are in place to slow down the spread of the virus and protect people's health. There is no truth to the claim that the government wants everyone inside for two weeks to change the batteries in birds. This is a nonsensical statement that has no factual basis. It is important to rely on credible sources of information and follow the guidelines of health experts to stay safe and healthy during these challenging times.

A 38-year-old man in Patna who tested positive for Covid-19 has died. He had serious kidney problems, which led to renal failure soon after he returned from Qatar. This is the first Covid-19 linked death of a non-senior citizen.

There is misinformation circulating in India suggesting that since it is a country of vegetarians, it will not be impacted by the #CoronaVirus epidemic like China was. This claim has no factual basis as there is no connection between vegetarianism and the virus. Additionally, the belief that the majority of Indians are vegetarians is a myth as 80% of the population are actually meat eaters.

A website has spread false information about the Indian Government considering imposing a Financial Emergency to address the COVID-19 crisis. This claim is untrue and should not be believed. Please be cautious and do not spread misleading information.

A man in Bihar, who was 38 years old, has died at AIIMS hospital in Patna after testing positive for COVID-19. He had recently traveled to Qatar.

Qatar has not provided a hospital to treat the migrant workers infected with the Coronavirus. This is unacceptable as the workers are human beings who have rights. Instead of medical care, they have been placed in animal shelters and are not receiving the proper treatment they need. It is unfortunate that human rights organizations have not raised their voices to speak out against this injustice.

Saif Ali had returned from Qatar and went to Munger, Bihar. Unfortunately, he became ill and was admitted to a hospital. He was referred to AIIMS but unfortunately passed away. Doctors discovered that he had contracted the Coronavirus. The police eventually reached his home and placed his entire family in quarantine. However, every member of the family has since left their home and many are feeling frightened.

He also advises people to continue going to work and school. This statement has caused social media users to use the hashtag #TrumpVirus, #COVID19, and #Coronvirus to express their concerns.

This is an unprecedented measure taken by Italy to tackle the spread of the virus.
